dt: {bc}given to prosy, rambling, or tedious {d_link|loquacity|loquacity} {bc}pointlessly or annoyingly talkative

pt: {sc}talkative{/sc} {sc}loquacious{/sc} {sc}garrulous{/sc} {sc}voluble{/sc} mean given to talk or talking. {sc}talkative{/sc} may imply a readiness to engage in talk or a disposition to enjoy conversation.
{sc}loquacious{/sc} suggests the power of expressing oneself articulately, fluently, or glibly.
{sc}garrulous{/sc} implies prosy, rambling, or tedious loquacity.
{sc}voluble{/sc} suggests a free, easy, and unending loquacity.

quotes.t: He was not {qword}garrulous{/qword} by any means. On the contrary, there was a fine reserve in his manner toward the entire domestic economy of his life which was all that is comprehended by the popular term, gentlemanly.
Salman grew ever more {qword}garrulous{/qword} as the yellow liquid in the bottle went down; Baal couldn't recall when he'd last heard anyone talk up such a storm.

To an American reader in 1982, confronted with this {qword}garrulous{/qword}, indefatigably quirky, I'm-just-typing-on-yellow-paper-and-associating-ideas-and-memories prose work of 1936, such a judgment, by a presumably informed person, seems preposterous.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}garrulus,{/it} from {it}garrīre{/it} "to chatter, talk rapidly" (probably of imitative origin) + {it}-ulus,{/it} deverbal suffix denoting inclination or repetitive action (going back to Indo-European {it}-l-,{/it} participial suffix) {ma}{mat|-ous|}{/ma}
For possible relation to a proposed Indo-European base {it}*ǵeh{inf}2{/inf}r-,{/it} see {et_link|care:1|care:1}.
shortdef: given to prosy, rambling, or tedious loquacity : pointlessly or annoyingly talkative
